bestBHT.bht: If anyone does not receive you, shake off the very dust from your feet as a testimony against them. This act signifies the finality of rejection and serves as a powerful witness against those who refuse to accept the message. When encountering hostility or rejection, the disciples were instructed to declare the Kingdom of God is near and move on, leaving the dust of that place behind. This action, first mentioned in Matthew 10:14, emphasizes the seriousness of rejecting the message of salvation.

Archibald T. Robertson: As many as receive you not (οσο αν μη δεχωντα υμας). Indefinite relative plural with αν and present middle subjunctive and the negative μη.
Here Matthew 10:14 has the singular (whosoever) and Mark 6:11 has 'whatsoever place.'
For a testimony against them (εις μαρτυριον επ' αυτους). Note use of επ' αυτους where Mark 6:11 has simply the dative αυτοις (disadvantage), really the same idea.
John Gill: And whosoever will not receive you... shake off the very dust from your feet, for a testimony against them."
Shake off the very dust from your feet"
